title: Childs Fall 2017 Menswear Collection - Vogue
text: by Steff Yotka The genius of Robert Childs’s menswear is that he is both a designer’s designer—his quality is truly impeccable—and a designer of the people, who typically spends hours considering how and why a guy would reach for a Childs jacket or suit. It’s this duality that has allowed him to develop a recognizable vernacular of smart utility-driven wear with a subversive sense of fun in three short seasons. For Fall 2017, perhaps as a response to the chaotic state of the world, Childs looked to two groups of guys with bad reputations: bikers and bankers. Bikers vs. Bankers is a punchy name for a collection that you will happily find printed nowhere on these clothes; in addition to being a pragmatist, he’s also not a follower of overhyped trends. Instead, he took an architectural approach to each group, turning the kneepads of motocross pants into large patches that wrap all the way to the backs of trousers and morphing the banker’s double-breasted suit into a shrunken thing in pinstripes fit for (his words) “an English super-villain.” Items from previous collections continue into Fall, including cropped workwear jackets with high, square pockets and cozy hoodies in washed-out hues. Some levity was introduced via a warm shade of periwinkle that came striped across tees and as a corduroy suit that he insisted looked less shocking on the body than on a rack. Read More
